MESSAGE FROM THE YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA

Column: 297

YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

(Debate on the Address)
(Fourth Day)


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on Question [5th August, l960],

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly."'.- (The Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.32 p.m.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, last Friday, I said that the brightest feature in the speech of His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara was the admission that there had been

Column: 298

mistakes and shortcomings, and that also the promise was made that in future there would be more patience and that zeal would be tempered with understanding. Sir, it seems to be a very good beginning, to undo those mistakes that have been made, and in the light of that promise, I would like to bring to the attention of the Government certain things which have brought about a great deal of unhappiness to many parents, teachers and students.

    Sir, the most important cause of much unhappiness amongst these people is the six-day week. The parents have said that they have noticed that their children show signs of undue strain. On Saturdays, they seem to have no relish for school work and, of course, homework must be given. As usual, on Sundays, they have to do their homework and on Monday the round begins again. So these perpetual rounds give no real break to students and those engaged in the teaching profession. Sir, it may be said that in the past the Chinese-medium schools had a six-day working week, but actually they had 5.5 days, as it was pointed out by the Minister for Education. That half a day was usually devoted to recreational activities. Now in England I have been told that two half days are devoted to recreational activities so that actually they too have five full days of school work. Sir, if it is important that extra languages must be taught, I suggest that it could be done by the substitution of an extra language period for a period that can be done away with. Or let the school start, say, half an hour earlier each day, but let there be a five-day week or a compulsory five-day week with half a day optional for most schools in Singapore.

    There was a meeting, Sir, in Kuala Lumpur on 6th June, 1960, and there was a report in the Free Press of 7th June, 1960, which stated that at the first session of the Asian regional conference of the World Confederation of Organisations of the Teaching Profession, the delegates came to the conclusion and recommended that the teaching period "should be fitted into a five-day week, for it is essential that children get a real break from school work each week.

Column: 299

Where home conditions are so poor that it is desirable for children to spend more time in school, this time should not be used for more teaching but for recreation and hobbies." Sir, that is the opinion of professional people at a world conference. Let us not forget, Sir, that by having a six-day week, poor parents must spend about 20 per cent more on their children's expenses in school. Let us not forget also that we are working here under climatic conditions that are different from those existing in temperate regions. I am sure some of the Members on the Government side, Sir, will remember that whereas in London, one can walk for miles and miles and for hours without feeling tired, we cannot do the same in the heat of a tropical country like Singapore. Sir, therefore, if the Government wishes to restore the morale of teachers, students and parents, we earnestly request them to consider the restoration of a five-day week or a five-day week plus a half day on Saturday for recreational activities.

    Sir, another sore point among teachers today is the new kind of formula which seems to go against all arithmetical principles. We used to learn that if we want more work to be done, we have to get more men. Today the formula seems to be: More activities, more work but less manpower. Of course, economy is very important, but you can go to such lengths that economy defeats the very purpose of introducing economic measures, when we have demoralising effects and when the standard of efficiency goes down. We have had cases where a teacher in, say, the Malay medium or the Chinese medium was called upon to substitute for a teacher in the English medium, to carry on a regular lesson in the English medium or vice versa, just because there was a shortage of teachers in a school.

    We all agree, Sir, that the principle of equal treatment is a principle we want to adopt, but in the measures adopted to implement this principle of equal treatment, let us make sure that equal treatment does not become equal Maltreatment. We all agree that there must be equal treatment. Sir, we hope

Column: 300

that these things will be looked into carefully and rectification be made.

    There is one point to be clarified under "University", Sir. In column 20 of Hansard dated 20th July, 1960 (Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech), it is stated:

    "...the two Universities, Nanyang University and the Singapore Division of the University of Malaya, are geared to serve the needs of the State.'

Sir, we hope by that it does not mean that the one to manipulate the gears is only the Government, but that before the gears are changed there will be consultation and that the views of the University authorities will be properly appreciated so that over there also there will not be this feeling that equal treatment means equal treatment on a lower level. We all want equal treatment on the higher level so that it becomes equally good treatment.

    Sir, we all desire to improve conditions and standards in education, but the improvements should not be such that the levels go down. I believe, Sir, that we can maintain the high standards of education in our country. On a five-day week we have produced brilliant scholars like our Prime Minister. Only three years ago we sent a local student to the London University and I have just received a report, Sir, that in the Engineering College (University of London), he topped the list of first-class honours last week. That, Sir, was on a five day week.

    Sir, I now come to the amendment standing in my name. I move,

    "at end, to add -

    `but urges the Government to consider restoring to its employees the cut in variable allowances which was made last year'."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I may be wrongly accused again for having brought this up in order to revive an old sore. Sir, let us consider again the facts of the case when the cut in the variable allowances of Government servants was introduced. About a year ago, when the Minister for Finance introduced the cut, Sir, the main reason given was that the Government faced a threatened deficit of $14 million. I pointed out then, Sir, that it was only a threatened deficit and that, judging

Column: 301

from what had been done by previous Financial Secretaries, an expected financial deficit usually turned out to be a surplus. But the Minister for Finance insisted that the ship was sinking, and that unless steps were taken it might be too late.

    Sir, in the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, we read in column 6 of Hansard dated 20th July, 1960:

    `The State ended the year's budget with a small surplus of $9 million.'

Sir, if there had been an expected deficit of $14 million and the year ended with a surplus of $9 million, then the Government has been able to make good by something like $23 million. I am not sure whether the financial year ended in November or December 1959 - I would normally expect it to be so - but if that were so, then in half a year they have made good the deficit and there was also a surplus of $9 million. Sir, the principle I would say is this: if we want to get rid of the deficit, the first thing should be to economise, not to cut the pay of our employees. As an example of a model employer, to resort to pay cuts should be the last thing, and not the first. If the surplus is money which has been obtained through the cut in the variable allowances, and since the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara states that the country is economically stable, the time seems to be favourable to rectify this mistake. We do not say that the mistake was intentional - we all make mistakes. But it is understood, Sir, that once errors are made and found out, it is only right that we should rectify them, otherwise they will remain errors and a running sore throughout.

    Sir, the Prime Minister was reported in the Straits Times of Friday, 3rd June, 1960, to have said the following:

    `There were some mistakes, and there were hard feelings. True, the cut in allowances of Government servants was painful. True, school teachers were pushed too far in the extra half session.

    Rectifications had to be made. Half sessions have been dropped. Professional allowances were paid to certain categories of officers in the Government service.'

Column: 302



    I am glad that the Prime Minister himself has admitted the principle that once errors are discovered, rectifications are necessary. However the rectifications have not been fully made. It may not be realised by many, Sir, that half sessions have not been completely withdrawn. The teachers were told that if they had not volunteered for the half sessions, their turn would come once in three years. So, actually the half sessions have not been completely dropped, and very likely the Prime Minister was misinformed. Sir, some people may say that I am going to benefit by this if Government should become generous. Let me say here, and I give you my word, Sir, that if anything comes out of it I do not wish to benefit from it. There may be others also who do not wish to benefit from it, and would be glad that if anything should come to some of us, that money be given to the unemployed. There are those who feel that the cut was very painful because they had committed themselves in advance to housing loans, education of their children, and I know of certain cases where the children have to be pulled back from universities because their parents could not afford to lose their allowances. Sir, this is a question not only of principle, but of sincerity, a test of sincerity. Just a last word, Sir. At the big rally at the Happy World Stadium of teachers in Singapore, the Prime Minister noticed the look of unhappiness among the many faces and, being a person who knows human nature well, suddenly introduced something in his speech. He promised the teachers that if things improved, although he was not the Finance Minister, he would recommend restoration of the pay cuts, if not all, at least part of it.

    The Prime Minister: On a point of clarification, Sir. May I -

    Mr Speaker: If the Member will give way.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: In a few seconds -

    The Prime Minister: It is very important.

Column: 303



    Mr Speaker: I think the Prime Minister will have the opportunity.

    The Prime Minister: I have been misquoted.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Sir, there was a big applause, and I was there. Sir, I cannot give the exact words, but the content was that. It can be verified by checking with the 9,000 or 10,000 teachers who were present. I hope that that is remembered, Sir, and, in principle, if Government cannot afford to restore all the allowances, at least the principle of restoration or rectification of error is, I think, important.

    I so move.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, may I -

    Mr Speaker: I think the Prime Minister will have the opportunity to speak on the amendment after I propose the Question.

    Question proposed, "That the words proposed to be added, be there added."

    Mr Speaker: Hon. Members will appreciate, of course, that the debate from now on until the amendment has been disposed of must be concentrated on the amendment itself.

    No Member rising -

    Mr Speaker: I cannot be kept waiting for long. If nobody wishes to speak, I will put the Question.

    Question, "That the words proposed to be added, be there added", put, and negatived.

    Amendment accordingly negatived.

    Mr Speaker: We are now back to the original Question.

    Original Question again proposed.

2.53 p.m.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib (Southern Islands)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, in moving the motion of thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, the Prime Minister mentioned that the Government was aware that Communist elements had been regrouping and reorganising in Singapore immediately before the last elections. This fact should be considered in the interests of the

Column: 304

peace and prosperity of the State of Singapore. If these Communist activities are allowed to go unchecked, it means that we condone them.

    Mr Speaker, it should be remembered that `at the present moment we are at the stage of achieving independence for Singapore. We realise that independence can only be achieved through a merger with the Federation of Malaya. We are sincere in wishing to achieve our aim, and should not give up halfway in our efforts because of our own acts, and without careful consideration of the ways and means of achieving our objective.

    I am fully confident, Mr Speaker, that what has been said by the Prime Minister has been said in an atmosphere of worry and the realisation of the dangers confronting the Government. But what I wish to know, Mr Speaker, is that during the last 14 months that the Government has been in office, what steps have the Prime Minister and his Cabinet taken to forestall or curb the threat of Communism? Has the Prime Minister been sitting still, a silent spectator to the activities of the Communists, and waiting for the moment when steps could be taken? Or has he resigned himself to fate, hoping for the best in the future? Or is that a further mistake made by the Government over the last 14 months? To the best of my knowledge, Mr Speaker, to-date I cannot recall any positive action taken by the Government in suppressing Communist subversive elements.

    Recently I heard it announced in this Assembly that two journalists had been detained under the P.P.S.O. on the ground that they were associated with pro-K.M.T. subversive elements. Mr Speaker, I hope the Prime Minister and Members of the Government will declare frankly their stand. I ask: are they prepared to get themselves mixed up and be involved with Communists? I warn them about the Malay proverb: "You cannot befriend the tiger." I say honestly that these methods are wrong. For these reasons, we are almost suspicious of the present Government. We will not change our stand so long

Column: 305

as the Government cannot come out into the open and take action to wipe out Communist activities, whether the activities are within their Party or outside. We will give our wholehearted support if the Government takes positive steps towards wiping out these Communist activities.

    For us, Mr Speaker, we are sincere, determined and honest in facing Communist subversion. There are people who allege that our opinions are based on fanaticism. But I would like to ask this. Is the concept of anti-colonialism also fanaticism? With this non-Communist policy, Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister has mentioned three possibilities that may happen to his Party. First, what is good for the P.A.P. may not be good for the M.C.P. What is good for the P.A.P. may also be good for the Communists. What is not good for the P.A.P. may be good for the Communists. Unfortunately, Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister has not given us examples as to the difference in meaning between the three possibilities mentioned by him. But if I could be `permitted to give an example of what may be good for the P.A.P. but not good for the Communists, we could say this-the Government's efforts to get help from the British Government will not be acceptable to the Communists. Secondly, on what is good for the P.A.P. may also be good for the Communists, I could say this. For instance, we repatriate all those in key posts still held by expatriates to their country of origin, and replace them with local personnel who the Government feel can do what they dictate. Whether they are competent or otherwise, it does not matter at all. Thirdly, the possibility that what is good for the P.A.P. may not be good for the Communists. For instance, Mr Speaker, recently the Singapore Government sent a congratulatory message to the Federation Government on the termination of the Emergency there. This action of the P.A.P. is taken because, if we do not offer our congratulations, it may not be good from the point of view of the

Column: 306

relationship between the two territories. But for the Communists this gesture is directly opposed to their interests.

    Mr Speaker, on the problem of merger with the Federation of Malaya, we realise that Singapore cannot survive by itself. But what we fail to understand is that we can only charge the Federation of Malaya for refusing to accept us as a unit of Malaya. Mr Speaker, we are only wise in pointing an accusing finger at a man if he is wrong. If we ourselves do not wish to rectify the mistakes that we have committed, or adopt an unacceptable attitude, then we cannot accuse the other Party of refusing to accept our views.

    We know, Mr Speaker, that by our merely saying that this is good and so on, it will have no effect on anybody. The listeners will weigh our words and consider our deeds and actions. Then only will they form certain conclusions. But if we preach one thing and practise another, then it follows that they will not have faith in us.

    The P.A.P., Mr Speaker, has admitted that the Malays in the Federation are afraid that a merger will mean that the Malay population there will be swallowed up. I want to be honest in this matter. It is not communalism - it is a fact which nobody can deny or repudiate. It should not be misconstrued that it is communalism, as though communalism is the greatest danger both in Singapore and the Federation of Malaya - putting aside the Communist threat. We consider it a small matter. It is wrong, Mr Speaker, to consider communalism in Malaya, because the multi-racial people have lived peacefully side by side for hundreds of years, and they have faced different political developments together until the creation of a Government for which all the people are responsible. Sir, there should be no reason why this problem should constitute a danger, although there are among us those who have no feelings of sympathy, and who simply refuse to see facts. They base their actions on sentiment, and exploit this communal issue for their own benefit. But if they see the facts for themselves based on sympathetic consideration, I think, Mr Speaker,

Column: 307

it will be clearly seen that from the time of British colonialism we can always come to a compromise to avoid undesirable events happening in Malaya.

    About the concern of the Malays in the Federation, at the moment I think they are having good hopes of living in a house comprising various races, and they are moving towards the building of one nation based on a strong foundation. But if we look at the situation in Singapore, Mr Speaker, Sir, we cannot foresee this hope, although we are working under a Government with a Constitution in which it has clearly been enunciated that positive steps should be taken to help the Malays. On this matter, all the relevant provisions cannot be distorted or twisted; as, for instance, by giving Malays free education. Free education has been given, from the primary level up to the middle school and university level. During the British era, free education was also in existence, and in the English schools were found special Malay classes. Special privileges were given to those in these classes.

    Similarly, in other matters, we cannot be proud of anything which leaves no impression at all. So what the Government should do is to initiate a special programme as required under the Constitution. Although Members of the Government charge that this is communalism, it is clearly enunciated in the preamble to the Constitution. We cannot set aside the Constitution if we are to go by the Constitution which we have all accepted.

    Mr Speaker, as has been mentioned by the Opposition side, we are reviewing the work of the Government during the 14 months they have been holding the reins of power. They should rectify the mistakes they have made.

    I am quite sure the Government will not find it hard to change their attitude and I feel they will fully implement the paragraph about the special rights of the Malays.

    There is one point which I would like to express, Mr Speaker, speaking on the inter-racial ties, and that is, special attention should be given to Malays of Islamic religion. The Malays are opposed to Communism. They are of the opinion

Column: 308

that the Communists are atheists. So also with Christianity and Buddhism - they are opposed to Communism. If the Government fail to adopt a positive attitude, it follows that the followers of the religion I have just mentioned will have no faith in them. They will not believe that the Government will take definite steps to curb Communist activities both in Singapore and Malaya.

    I would like to give an illustration which may be a little shocking to the Muslim population. A concert about "Ketuhanan", meaning godliness, was recently presented over the Malay Section of Radio Singapore. This story, Mr Speaker, has resulted in protestations coming from the Muslim people. One section feels that the presentation of this concert has caused the Holy Koran to be insulted or looked down upon with contempt, whereas another section feels that this is a progressive move. There is yet another group which is of the opinion that this is Communist propaganda to test how deep is the faith of the Muslim people towards Islam. This sort of thing will create an unhealthy atmosphere. A close scrutiny will make it obvious that it will result in clashes between various people of different faiths, and that it will be bad for Singapore's peace and prosperity. I hope the Ministry responsible will conduct an investigation so that there will be no recurrence of such a thing. I am suspicious of the Government's attitude. The Government, on the one hand, realises that Communist activities are becoming more active. On the other hand, it has not produced a White Paper so that the public will know what it stands for. If I am not mistaken, the previous Government issued a White Paper declaring its stand and mentioning how Communist activities had been on the rampage, subverting trade unions and other cultural bodies. But in Singapore during the past 14 months the Government has not done anything positive or definite to control the people's associations, trade unions, etc. We would like to know what the Communists have done during the past 14 months that the P.A.P. has been in power. If the Government really wishes to make the people realise the danger of

Column: 309

Communism, it is important that it should issue a White Paper on the subject.

    Mr Speaker, in addition to what I have already said, it is hoped that the Government, in the year ahead will pay attention to and take steps on the matters which the Opposition has raised, because the time has come when we do not wish to be considered any longer as, to quote the Prime Minister, "gunny bags fit for bayonet practices by the Japanese". We are not here just to offer blind opposition, but we are here to offer and have offered constructive and useful criticisms. We have given the Government an opportunity to show their capabilities by carrying out plans which are beneficial to the people. It is clear now that the matters raised by the Opposition have caused the Government to consider them seriously. For instance, the Trade Unions Bill. Although the Government did pass the Trade Unions Bill in this Assembly, I am quite sure that the Government has now given second thoughts to it, as it will be re-introduced at a later date.

    Another point on which I would like to touch in this Assembly, Mr Speaker, is the good relationship between the Indonesian and Singapore Governments. The people of Singapore gladly welcome this. But on behalf of the inhabitants of the Southern Islands, I would like to raise this point in this Assembly, and that is, that this Government will convey to the Indonesian Government, on the basis of our good relationship, the hopes of the inhabitants concerning the methods of entry into Indonesian-owned islands. I know of the existing facilities accorded to the fishermen on the Southern Islands to fish in Indonesian territorial waters which have been going on well, but what I have in mind is the relationship between the inhabitants of the Southern Islands and those of a neighbouring island outside the jurisdiction of Singapore [meaning an island in Indonesia]. Some of these people who are Singapore

Column: 310

citizens marry Indonesian subjects, living on the neighbouring island. From time immemorial, they have had this social intercourse. Now they are encountering difficulties with the Immigration Department. What I am told is that in the past they were issued with special identity cards valid for one year, and the possession of these special identity cards would enable them to move freely between the Indonesian Islands for the specific purposes, as mentioned on the identity cards. I hope this system will be reintroduced by the Immigration Department, as it will facilitate entry of the wives or children into Singapore, the object of which is relationship between one family and another.

    Apart from that, Mr Speaker, I hope the Minister for Education will be in a position in the coming year to build a school on Blakan Mati. I am told by the Education Ministry that the school at Blakan Mati in the past year was outside the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Education. It was at the time under the control of the Ministry of National Development. For this year, however, there is a school site and building plans have been completed, except that the Education Ministry has no money at its disposal, and I hope this year a school will be built on Blakan Mati because the difficulties faced by the pupils are great indeed in that they have to travel by ferry across to the island of Blakan Mati. Sometimes they experience difficulties in using the ferry supplied by the War Department.

    Similarly with the Prime Minister who is in charge of rural areas. During the past year there was no vote for the development of these two islands - Blakan Mati and Pulau Brani. Hence in the coming year I believe there are provisions for the development of Pulau Brani. One of the things for the Ministry to provide is a jetty in the kampong called Telok Saga. At the moment the people there are using, as a bridge, only a piece of timber, which is dangerous.

Column: 311



3.29 p.m.

    Mr Tee Kim Leng (Pasir Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. is a Party of strength and full of revolutionary spirit. It will not accept any compromise with the colonialists. Before the general elections last year, we expounded our Five-Year Plan. At present, the Government of the self-governing State of Singapore works under certain restrictions contained in the Constitution. The Government has therefore found it quite impossible to fulfill all the hopes and aspirations of the people. The P.A.P. Government will not disappoint the people because of the restrictions contained in the Constitution. The achievements of the past year have clearly shown that the P.A.P. Government has been doing its best - although restricted by the Constitution - to fulfill the desires and hopes of the people, especially in the expansion of local industries.

    However, Mr Speaker, our colleagues and I are still not satisfied with the Constitution. Our aims are the same as those of our people. If the people want to achieve their aims, they must always stand united with a Left-wing political Party that is firm in its policies. Such a party is the P.A.P. Our Party is a Party that has the best political policies in the history of Malayan nationalism. Being a Left-wing Party and an up-holder of nationalism, we will not lose sight of the original noble objectives of our struggle (we have a long-term aim) amidst the political turmoil, and we will not be made use of by any political opportunists.. All intelligent Left-wing thinkers are able to analyse the present situation of political unrest and turmoil. No matter what the political opportunists will do, or have done, they will fail, just like Mr Marshall's Workers' Party. The progressive forces are always united together and will struggle against colonialism and semi-feudalism to the end. At the same time, the P.A.P will continue to struggle by not wavering from its firm policies.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the people know that, since the P.A.P. came into power and governed the State under the Constitution, we have been enforcing our

Column: 312

revolutionary policies to reform Government organisations, to cut out unnecessary expenses, to wipe out bureaucracy, to end corruption completely and to make public servants more polite and courteous to the public. These policies will be enforced as long as the P.A.P. is in power. If anyone tries to disrupt us, we will take the necessary action to suppress him.

    The continuous increase of population has created more unemployment among the young people. The Government attaches great importance to the creation of more jobs for the young people. For this reason, the Government is trying its best to expand local industries all the time. This year will see the beginning of industrial expansion and it will also be a year that will decide the future of the P.A.P. The l½ million people of the State will begin to enjoy an era of economic and political stability. There is no limit to industrial expansion.
